importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The outage occurred on Monday, October 20, 2025, at approximately 07:11 GMT, marking the start of a major disruption in AWS services that affected global digital infrastructure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage lasted approximately three hours, from 07:11 GMT to 10:11 GMT, during which 113 AWS services failed, impacting critical online platforms globally.

keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a major outage due to an error in a technical update to DynamoDB's API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS) and prevented apps from connecting to essential services.
The root cause was a DNS failure caused by an incorrect update to DynamoDB, a core cloud database service that stores user data for numerous platforms.

Over 113 AWS services were affected, including major apps such as Snapchat, Pinterest, Apple TV, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Starbucks, Duolingo, Canva, and financial services like Venmo and Coinbase.
The outage highlighted the critical dependence of modern digital life — from banking and gaming to smart home devices and media consumption — on cloud infrastructure.
The incident was not due to a cyberattack or external threat, but rather attributed to human error, a common cause of cloud outages.
AWS acknowledged the issue, deployed multiple recovery paths, and reported full restoration by 10:11 GMT, though some users faced delays in service recovery.
AWS remains the dominant global cloud provider, holding approximately 30% of the market share, which makes such outages highly visible and impactful due to widespread reliance on its services.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage at Amazon Web Services (AWS) on October 20, 2025, caused widespread disruption to critical online services, including banking apps, gaming platforms, social media, media outlets, and smart home devices. The failure originated in AWS’s Virginia data center due to a technical update that caused a DNS failure in DynamoDB’s API, preventing apps from connecting to essential servers. Over 113 AWS services were affected, impacting platforms such as Snapchat, WhatsApp, Roblox, Venmo, and major news organizations. The outage, attributed to human error rather than a cyberattack, highlighted the deep reliance of modern digital life on cloud infrastructure. AWS acknowledged the issue, deployed rapid recovery measures, and restored services by 10:11 GMT, though some users faced delays. The incident underscores the fragility and critical importance of cloud computing in today’s interconnected world.
